blocks.title: Free Hosting Platform Comparison
rows: GitHub Pages
Completely free, suitable for static websites; seamless integration with GitHub Repo / Actions; supports custom domains and automatic SSL; beginner-friendly with abundant learning resources
Only supports static content; no built-in backend/Serverless; approximately 1GB storage, ~10 deployments per hour limit; limited access speed in some regions
Netlify
Git-connected one-click CI/CD, Deploy Preview; built-in Netlify Functions, forms, authentication; global CDN, custom domain + SSL; high level of automation
Free plan uses point quota system (approximately 300 points per month); limited function execution time/memory; high traffic and advanced features require payment
Vercel
Zero-configuration deployment, Next.js friendly; Preview URL, instant rollback; Serverless/Edge Functions; global Edge Network with excellent performance
Hobby plan has traffic/request/function time quotas; limited large-scale backend capabilities; source code size/deployment frequency limits
Lovable
AI-assisted frontend, backend, and database generation; WYSIWYG editing; one-click deployment with domain binding; offers free trial to experience full workflow
Backend tends toward specific services like Supabase; complex projects require engineer intervention; rapid feature updates and smaller quotas, long-term strategy undefined

blocks.title: Paid Hosting Platform Comparison
rows: AWS
Most comprehensive cloud services; S3+CloudFront/Amplify meet various architecture needs; high scalability and security; pay-as-you-go pricing with flexibility
High learning curve, complex configuration; complex fee structure requiring cost monitoring; infrastructure maintenance responsibility on users
WordPress.com
Mature CMS with plugin ecosystem (from business plans); quick content website launch; free starting point with flexible upgrades
Lower-tier plans cannot install plugins; PHP architecture limits frontend customization freedom; high traffic affected by platform resource sharing
Wix
Drag-and-drop editor with rich templates; app marketplace and SEO/marketing tools; hosting and maintenance all-inclusive for peace of mind
Low code customization freedom; platform lock-in making migration difficult; higher costs for advanced features/e-commerce
Squarespace
High-quality templates with consistent style; comprehensive official feature integration; mobile-friendly with good customer support
No permanent free plan; lower freedom than Wix/self-hosted; smaller plugin ecosystem with limited customization

blocks.content: Demo: Deploy a Small Website to Vercel (My Most Used Platform)

items: Prepare a website (including index.html) and push it to a GitHub Repository.
Log in to your Vercel account (you can log in directly with GitHub).
Select **New Project** in the Vercel Dashboard.
Authorize and connect your GitHub Repository.
Select the project to deploy, Vercel will automatically detect and configure.
After completion, Vercel will provide a default domain name for accessing the website.

blocks.alt: Demonstration of how to automatically deploy a static website from GitHub to Vercel

blocks.content: üìå Push updates to GitHub, and Vercel will automatically redeploy to keep the website up to date.

blocks.title: Pro Tip
blocks.content: Both Netlify and Vercel support GitHub / GitLab / Bitbucket automatic deployment - just push your code to automatically update the website.
